title: Domain 1.11: Identify common features and tools of the Linux client/desktop OS.
content:
üîß Common Linux Commands

  • ls: Lists directory contents.
  • pwd: Prints the current working directory path.
  • mv: Moves or renames files and directories.
  • cp: Copies files or directories.
  • rm: Deletes files or directories.
  • chmod: Changes file permissions (e.g., read, write, execute).
  • chown: Changes file ownership (user and group).
  • su / sudo: Executes commands with superuser privileges or switches users.
  • apt-get: Package management for Debian-based distros (e.g., Ubuntu).
  • yum: Package manager for Red Hat-based distros (e.g., CentOS, RHEL).
  • ip: Configures network interfaces and views network information.
  • df: Shows disk space usage for mounted filesystems.
  • grep: Searches text using pattern matching (e.g., log analysis).
  • ps: Lists running processes.
  • man: Opens manual pages for other commands (e.g., man ls).
  • top: Displays live system resource usage and active processes.
  • find: Locates files based on name, size, or other criteria.
  • dig: DNS lookup utility (great for troubleshooting domain issues).
  • cat: Displays file contents in the terminal.
  • nano: Terminal-based text editor, ideal for beginners.

üõ°Ô∏è Best Practices

  • Backups: Regularly back up configs, user data, and system state.
  • Antivirus: Install tools like ClamAV to scan for malware (especially in shared environments).
  • Updates: Apply patches and updates frequently to stay secure and stable.

üß∞ Useful Linux Tools

  • Shell/Terminal: CLI interface used to interact with the OS.
  • Samba: Enables file and printer sharing between Linux and Windows systems.
